verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all Israel had come to Shechem to make him king.
verses.comment: Place names remain the same as in the Hebrew; Shechem as the place of coronation.

verses.text: When Jeroboam the son of Nebat heard about this—he was still in Egypt where he had fled from King Solomon—he returned from Egypt.
verses.comment: Mentions Jeroboam in exile; follows the narrative chronology.

verses.text: So they sent and called for him, and Jeroboam and all the assembly of Israel came and said to Rehoboam,
verses.comment: Faithful to the original; 'assembly' for 'congregation.'

verses.text: "Your father made our yoke heavy. Now, therefore, lighten the hard service of your father and his heavy yoke that he put on us, and we will serve you."
verses.comment: 'Yoke' kept as metaphor for burden; original speech pattern preserved.

verses.text: He said to them, "Go away for three days, then come back to me." So the people went away.
verses.comment: Literal translation of Hebrew time and action.

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam consulted with the elders who had served his father Solomon while he was alive, saying, "How do you advise me to answer these people?"
verses.comment: Accurately preserves who the elders are and the king's question.

verses.text: They said to him, "If you will be a servant to these people today, serve them, and speak good words to them when you answer them, then they will be your servants forever."
verses.comment: "Servant" as per original; advice to serve and speak kindly.

verses.text: But he abandoned the advice the elders gave him and consulted the young men who had grown up with him and stood before him.
verses.comment: Literal rendering, 'stood before him' meaning 'served as attendants.'

verses.text: He said to them, "What do you advise that we answer these people who said to me, 'Lighten the yoke your father put on us'?"
verses.comment: Keeps 'yoke' and speech form.

verses.text: The young men who had grown up with him said to him, "Say this to these people who said to you, 'Your father made our yoke heavy, but you lighten it for us.' Say to them, 'My little finger is thicker than my father's thighs.'"
verses.comment: 'Little finger' and 'thighs' are literal; denotes severity and idiom.

verses.text: "Now, whereas my father put a heavy yoke on you, I will add to your yoke. My father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
verses.comment: 'Scorpions' possibly refers to whips with barbs; kept literal.

verses.text: So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king had ordered, saying, "Come back to me on the third day."
verses.comment: Repeats the king's previous command as in the original.

verses.text: The king answered the people harshly and abandoned the advice the elders had given him.
verses.comment: 'Harshly' follows Hebrew for 'rough'; 'abandoned advice' literal.

verses.text: He spoke to them according to the advice of the young men, saying, "My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add to your yoke. My father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
verses.comment: Repeat of the advice from verse 11; adhered to original speech.

verses.text: So the king did not listen to the people, for this turn of events was from the LORD, in order that he might fulfill the word the LORD had spoken by Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.comment: Clearly states God's sovereignty and fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: When all Israel saw that the king did not listen to them, the people answered the king, "What portion do we have in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse. To your tents, Israel! Now look to your own house, David!" So Israel went to their tents.
verses.comment: 'To your tents' is a Hebrew idiom for 'go home.'

verses.text: But as for the people of Israel who lived in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam still ruled over them.
verses.comment: 'Remained' and 'ruled' literal.

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam sent Adoram, who was over the forced labor, but all Israel stoned him to death with stones. King Rehoboam quickly mounted his chariot to flee to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Adoram's office and stoning retained; 'forced labor' instead of 'tribute.'

verses.text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day.
verses.comment: 'To this day' notes completion of the schism.

verses.text: And when all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent and called him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. Only the tribe of Judah followed the house of David.
verses.comment: Judah as the only tribe remaining with David's dynasty.

verses.text: When Rehoboam came to Jerusalem, he assembled all the house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin, 180,000 chosen warriors, to fight against the house of Israel, to restore the kingdom to Rehoboam the son of Solomon.
verses.comment: 'Warriors' instead of 'men of war'; kept numbers as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: But the word of God came to Shemaiah the man of God, saying,
verses.comment: Shemaiah as prophet is literal.

verses.text: "Say to Rehoboam the son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all the house of Judah and Benjamin, and to the rest of the people,
verses.comment: Direct address from God to Shemaiah, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: 'Thus says the LORD, "You shall not go up or fight against your relatives the people of Israel. Every man must return to his home, for this thing is from me."'" So they listened to the word of the LORD and went back, according to the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Relatives' for 'brothers'; emphasis on divine command.

verses.text: Then Jeroboam built Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim and lived there. He went out from there and built Penuel.
verses.comment: 'Built' includes fortifying or expanding.

verses.text: Jeroboam said in his heart, 'Now the kingdom may return to the house of David.
verses.comment: Jeroboam's inner thoughts rendered literal.

verses.text: If these people go up to offer sacrifices in the house of the LORD at Jerusalem, the heart of this people will turn back to their lord, to Rehoboam king of Judah. Then they will kill me and return to Rehoboam king of Judah."
verses.comment: Faithful to original; speech reflects fear of loyalty shift.

verses.text: So the king took counsel and made two golden calves. He said to the people, "You have gone up to Jerusalem long enough. Here are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt."
verses.comment: Direct reference to Exodus 32 (golden calf sin).

verses.text: He set one in Bethel, and the other he put in Dan.
verses.comment: Literal; place names retained.

verses.text: And this thing became a sin, for the people went as far as Dan to worship the one there.
verses.comment: 'Sin' is the theological assessment of idolatry.

verses.text: Jeroboam also made temples on high places and appointed priests from among all the people, who were not from the Levites.
verses.comment: 'High places' refers to unauthorized worship sites.

verses.text: Jeroboam instituted a feast on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, like the feast that was in Judah, and he offered sacrifices on the altar. In this manner he did in Bethel, sacrificing to the calves he had made. He stationed at Bethel the priests of the high places he had made.
verses.comment: 'Feast' is an imitation of the Feast of Tabernacles.

verses.text: He went up to the altar that he had made in Bethel on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, in the month that he had devised in his own heart. He instituted a feast for the people of Israel and went up to the altar to make offerings.
verses.comment: 'Devised in his own heart' rendering follows Hebrew idiom.
